Variation Example: (Inclusa) A knight & a lady dream of each other & fall in love. He finds her in a tower behind ten locked doors. Her husband always keeps the key with him. The knight joins his service and, having earned his respect, is permitted to build a house next to the tower. The knight has a tunnel constructed between his house & the tower, & to ensure secrecy, he kills the architect. He is able easily to visit his lover, who gives him her ring. When the husband sees that the knight has this ring, he becomes suspicious. He goes quickly to his wife, who, because of the tunnel, now has the ring herself. Later the knight introduces the wife to her husband as his (i.e. the knight’s) wife. The husband again is suspicious, but, because of the tunnel, finds his wife back where she belongs. In the end the husband is so confused that he cannot recognize himself any more. He is tricked into marrying his wife off to the knight, without recognizing who she is. The couple escapes safely away on a ship.

Classifications: Husband Frightened by Wife's Lover in Hog Pen
Variation Example: When a wife & her lover are surprised by her husband’s sudden return, she quickly puts her lover into the hog pen. When the husband hears suspicious noises, he calls out, “Who are you?” The lover grunts, “I am only a poor hog”. The husband thinks his hog is possessed by the devil (and runs away).

A man unexpectedly comes home in order to get some warmer trousers. His wife gives him her lover’s trousers by mistake. This lover is a clergyman (shepherd, major, neighbor, butcher). Later she explains to her husband that she belongs to a religious order for which she has to wear such trousers.

Classifications: Woman Warns Lover of Husband by Singing Song
Variation Example: A wife has a lover who visits her regularly when her husband is away. One time her husband stays home unexpectedly. When the lover knocks on the door, the wife sings a lullaby in despair in which she warns him & tells him to go away. Or, when there is a knock on the door at night, the wife tells her husband it must be a ghost, & they both say prayers. The lover under stands the warning & goes away.

A husband comes home unexpectedly when his wife is with her lover. The lover hides & the wife pretends to be ill. She asks her husband to get her some water (medi cine, gin, an apple, etc.) which, she says, is the only thing that will cure her. After the husband goes out to get the water, the lover secretly escapes.
This misc. type includes various tales dealing with a lover who gives a gift to his mistress & takes it back by means of a trick.

A man seduces a woman by means of a gift (jewelry, ring, coat, dress, silk, fur, fish, etc.). When he leaves, he (intentionally) breaks a glass (jug). When the husband returns, the visitor tells him that the wife has taken the object as compensation for the damage. The husband gives the gift back to the visitor.

A farmer, bringing a load of wood to a nobleman, gives his horse & wagon to the nobleman’s wife in re-turn for sexual favors. He tells her husband that she kept the horse & wagon because she found a bad piece of wood in the load. The husband lets him keep the horse & wagon.

Classifications: Borrowing from the Husband & Returning to the Wife
Variation Example: A lover borrows money from a husband & uses it to seduce the man’s wife. Later he tells the husband that he repaid the debt while the husband was away. He shows him evidence or tells him where to find the money. The wife has to give the money back to her husband.
A man gives a woman money in order to seduce her. Later, he accidentally tells her husband about this. The husband forces his wife to restore the money.

A farmer selling a goose refuses to take money for it; instead, he wants to sleep with the woman who is buying it. The woman agrees & they sleep together. He refuses to give her the goose because, he says, she had more pleasure than he did for she had taken the upper position. After a second copulation in a different position, he claims that now they are even. While they are fighting about this, the woman’s husband comes & is told that they were quarreling about the price of the goose. He settles the fight by paying for the goose, & is thus doubly swindled.

A parrot (another bird) tells a man that his wife is an adulteress. When the husband has to go on a journey, he orders the parrot to give him a report on his wife’s behavior when he returns. The wife & her maidservant plan a trick: in the night they pour water through a hole in the roof onto the parrot, throw things at him, blind him with mirrors, & make noise like thunder. When the husband returns, the weather has been fine, but the parrot complains about the thunderstorm. Hearing what he believes to be a falsehood, the angry husband disbelieves everything the parrot says, & kills him. In some variants the husband goes up on the roof & discovers evidence of the deceit. He forgives his wife, kills her, or falls into despair.

With her husband nearby, a wife climbs up a tree ostensibly to pick fruit but really to meet her lover. The rest of the anecdote follows one of two patterns: (1) Although the husband sees his wife together with her lover, she convinces him that this was an optical illusion caused by the magic power of the tree (window, other objects). (2) The husband is old & blind & therefore very suspicious & jealous. In his delusion of love he embraces the trunk of the tree in order to protect his wife’s virtue from the eyes of passersby. At the critical moment, God (Jesus, Jupiter, St. Peter) restores his eye sight. He cries out in surprise, & his wife realizes what has happen ed. She assuages his anger by pointing out that her arborial adultery provided the means of restoring his eyesight.

(fingers) to unborn child. A clergyman (neighbor, friend) seduces a pregnant woman by telling her that her fetus has not been constructed properly by her husband. He offers to add the missing parts (nose, ears, head, limbs) for her. In some variants, the tale continues: When the husband returns home, he thanks the clergyman for his help. Or, the husband takes revenge by inviting the clergyman & his daughter to dinner. He steals the daughter’s ring & convinces that it has gone inside her body. He offers to retrieve it by having sex with her, & she agrees.

Classifications: Wife Recovers What Her Husband First Found & Then Lost
Variation Example: A man finds money which he gives to a beggar. (His wife spends the money. When her husband returns home, he falls into despair & wants to divorce her because of her stupidity.) His wife takes her son & follows the beggar in order to get the money back. She spends the night with the beggar, pretending to be a widow & that she & her child have vulgar names. During the night she takes the money & goes home. The beggar follows her, calling the vulgar names, which makes the passersby think he is insane.

An innocent young woman asks how she should serve God, & is told that she should avoid earthly pleasures. She goes into the wilderness where she finds a hermit & asks him what she must do to lead a pious life. The hermit tells her about God’s greatest enemy, the devil, whom people who love God must send back down to hell. He tells her his penis is the devil, & that instead of a devil she has a hell. Thus she is seduced into helping him send the devil into hell, believing that this will serve God.

Classifications: Why the Seventh Child has Red Hair
Variation Example: A dying husband asks his wife why six of their children have hair alike, but only the seventh has red hair. If the seventh’s father is someone else? “No, only seventh is yours”, explains the wife.

Classifications: The Wife Kept in a Box.
Variation Example: Two brothers (kings, knight & king, friends) discover that their wives have lovers. Hoping to distance themselves from this problem, the brothers set out on a journey. They meet a man (fakir, demon, etc.) who carries a small case (shrine) with him. When the man takes a rest, he opens the case & a beautiful woman comes out. The couple enjoy themselves & the man goes to sleep. The woman then seduces the two travelers. (Or, she also releases a lover from such a case that she carried with her.) So the brothers (the man himself) realize that even a well-guarded woman can betray her husband, & go back home knowing that there is no way to prevent women’s treachery.

A husband whose wife continually quarrels with him beats her. A passerby (healer, old woman, magician, hermit) gives her some “magic water”. As long as she keeps it in her mouth, she stops quarreling.

Classifications: Man & His Wife Build Air Castles
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) A poor married couple (father & son, two brothers, herds-men, maidservants, other people) plan to turn their possessions (glassware, milk, honey, eggs, money) into great wealth (herds of animals, houses). As they imagine this wealth, they destroy what they already have. (2) A person (poor man, hunter, Gypsy, married couple) dreams of having a valuable possession (catch from hunting, etc.), which he then tries to obtain. His efforts fail because he imagines his success (e.g. the hunter is so excited that he frightens his prey). (3) A married couple (other people) imagine that they will obtain the means to achieve future wealth, but they disagree about how to manage it. One wants to keep reinvesting the future profits, while the other wants to enjoy part of the wealth.

Classifications: Foolish Concerns for an Unborn Child
Variation Example: A married couple make plans for their future child. While they discuss what they want to do for this child, whom to invite to the birth, how the child should be raised, whether to let the child ride on a donkey, etc., they get into a serious quarrel.

A man notices that his wife & a farmhand yawn one after the other, & sees in this evidence of adultery. Plan-ning to hang his supposedly-unfaithful wife, he takes a rope & goes with her into the forest. He runs from one tree to another, trying to find one suitable for his purpose. The wife follows him & says that he behaves just like a rabbit (squirrel, bird) jumping all around. She tells him that his behavior is just like people’s yawns, which go from one person to another. This cures the husband of his suspicions, & the couple go back home together.

Classifications: The Cuckoo Calls from Inside the Cask
Variation Example: A nobleman courts a farm-er’s daughter. When he comes to take her away, he cannot find her because she hides from him. After he has searched for her with no success, he hears a voice from inside a cask calling “Cuckoo!” He finds her & takes her away. In older variants, an abbess hides a nun from a knight. The knight looks for her but soon gives up his search. She tells him where she is by calling “Cuckoo!” After their tryst, the knight abandons the nun.

A dying woman asks her husband (son) to say something sweet. He replies, “Honey”. Or a man who has been told to discipline only with good words hits his wife on the head with a prayer book. In some variants, a simple man (husband) is told to speak only round, i.e. good, words (to speak about big & deep, i.e. wise, things). He names only round (big & deep) objects.

A tenant farmer (neighbor, miller) promises his beautiful daughter against her will to his master. On the wedding day the master sends a farmhand to take “that which was promised to him”. The father sends him to the field where the daughter is at work, & she gives the messenger a mare. His master tells him to take that which he brought into the bedroom (the mare is dressed as a bride & put into the bed). In some variants the daughter calls herself (the father calls his daughter) “Mrs. Donkey” (“Mrs. Horse”) by ruse. When the master asks for “Mrs. Donkey”, the messenger brings a real donkey.

A man (priest) pays to be permitted to spend the night beside a young woman. She acts bashful & nervous, so he agrees to come in the dark. The next morning, he finds beside him an ugly old woman (wooden figure, heap of excrements).

A young woman is brought to an old man to spend the night with him. During the night she smears herself with black The next morning, when the man sees the black face beside him, he thinks he has slept with the devil.

A godfather would like to have an affair with a godmother. She agrees to meet him in the barn but sends her husband to meet him. The godfather says he only wants some straw. The same thing happens in the pigsty (sheep or cow stall), & the godfather tells the husband that he heard he had piglets to sell. The godmother invites her suitor into the house & he hides in the oven. When the husband finds him there, he says he was only measuring it. Finally the suitor turns up in their bed, & he claims he is there because he made a bet that the husband does not have two testicles (is circumcised).

An unmarried man & woman meet on their journeys & spend the night together in a single room. They sleep in the same bed with a pillow between them. The next day, the woman’s hat is blown over a wall (hedge). When the man goes to get it for her, she objects, “No, if you could not climb over the pillow last night, you certainly can’t climb over this wall!”
When the queen was told that the poor people had no bread, she answered, “Let them eat cake!”

A man & a woman swear to each other not to drink any wine except on market day. Then they open their own market where they sell their own donkey to each other. Or a woman swears to drink only after concluding a bargain. She sells & buys the same wares many times in one day.

Two men (husband & wife) sell small quantities of schnapps (wine) to each other always for the same coin. Each time, the buyer drinks the glass of schnapps. In the end they have only the single coin as payment for the entire cask (and they believe they have been robbed).
In order to rid herself of her old father-in-law, a woman gives him hard, burned bread to eat. Instead of starving, he grows healthier. Then she gives him soft, underbaked bread, & he soon dies.

Classifications: The Stingy Hostess at the Inn
Variation Example: A stingy woman (innkeeper, house-wife, farmwife) says that her guests are welcome to eat whatever they want, but unfortunately she has no spoons to give them. A clever man brings his own spoon (the needed spoons).

A (supposed) suitor visits the family of a marriageable young woman. Her parents send her to the cellar to fetch something for the visitor to drink. While drawing the drink the woman grows despondent over the fate of a child she might have after she is mar-ried. She worries about his cradle or his name, or weeps because she fears he will be killed by a tool (hammer, knife, hoe, stone) that may fall down on him, or an illness that may kill him. Her parents come to see what is the matter with their daughter. She tells them her worries & they too begin to weep. Meanwhile all the drink pours out of the cask, & the suitor leaves the house.
A thrifty young woman weaves herself a dress from flax that her sister carelessly dropped on the floor. When the sister’s suitor learns of this, he leaves the lazy sister & marries the thrifty one.

A suitor wants to be sure he marries a good wife. He observes three young women (sisters) eating cheese (apples). The first eats the cheese with its rind. The second cuts the rind off, but discards some good cheese as well. He chooses (his mother advises him to marry) the third sister because she is careful & thrifty, & discards only the rind.

A suitor puts a key into the flax which a seemingly-industrious young woman (according to her mother’s or her own statement) is about to spin into thread. On a later day he finds the key still there, & thus knows that the woman is lazy. Or, a suitor tests three young women. Only the youngest finds the key that he has hidden in the flax, so she is the one whom he marries.

A suitor who wants to choose a bride sees a young woman who bakes (cooks) while a drop is hanging from her nose. He decides to marry her only if the drop does not fall. When it falls into the dough (bowl), he leaves. Or, the suitor has come to find out whether or not the young woman is a neat housekeeper.

A suitor discovers that his fiancée still has dough under her fingernails three weeks after she last baked. He decides not to marry her. (He chooses a young woman with proper fingernails.) In some variants the suitor remarks that he has not been able to find seven-year-old mash, which was prescribed for him as medicine. The mother of his fiancée tells him they have old mash adhering to their pots & pans. The suitor leaves.
